content.description: Start on Hueco Dreams jug and traverse right into the Leap Frog dyno.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter or two for the dyno.
content.location: Starts on the lowest heavily chalked jug on the left side of the Who Needs Hueco cave.

content.description:
Short power problem that busts out the roof on the left side.  Start on a heavily chalked jug under the left side of the roof.  Make a left handed move to pinch a tufa like feature, then make two more moves setting yourself up on sidepulls and throw to the jug up and over the lip.  Tuck those feet in to avoid dabbing and undoing that precise throw you just made.   Top out from there. 

  Fun, but I still want to go to Hueco.
content.protection: pad but you are really close to the ground.
content.location: Left side of the pond cave.

content.description: another variation of leap frog.eliminate lower block for feet .start on the underclings in quartz block make hard move to the angled crack and move right to the arete keep those feet up! and make a few slotty bumps up crimps and finish straight up the arete.
content.location: start for leap frog var.

content.description: Start on right side of cave as for Quiet Buddhist, traverse left along back wall of cave to start of Who Needs Hueco, climb out finishing on Gravity Hits.  Very contrived...
Sit start for Sphincteral Agony. The block is off.
content.location: Starts on Leap Frog underclings.

content.description: Start as for Leap Frog and climb up to good hold above crack.  Instead of making the big dyno for Leap Frog, move left through small holds to a high scary topout.

Why top out the same old same old classic climbs you've done countless times before. With this line you get the satisfaction of the fun classic moveset with a topout incorporating a bit more of an adrenaline rush.
content.location: Start at either location of the Buddhist problems and traverse your way up the arete. Instead of the normal topout, crank on a heel to reach up into the roof on your right and topout straight over the overhang same finish as Sphincteral Agony.

content.description: Calling all short scrunchy climbers, do I have a problem for you.  Hidden up in a cave above Pond Cave Area your way through some overhung moves into a very delicate and difficult topout. Make sure to not touch any rock or tree other than the overhung portion or you lose.
content.location: This problem is located above the cave section at Pond Cave and is in it's own little cave area.Start on a good left hand flake and a sharp right hand crimp side pull under the right roof section. Delicately work your way up through some good crimps to the topout ledge. Now comes the difficult part of squeezing yourself through the topout without dabbing other rocks or the tree behind you. Has potential for a lower sit start but it was wet when I developed this.  Fun moveset but very high dab potential.

content.description:
Starts sitting on a jug under the roof to the left of the start of the Pond Cave Traverse. Make a big move as far up the arête as you can, then use a cool hold in the roof to join the arête and top out up and left using heel hooks, the same as for the Buddhist. Basically, start left under the roof and join the Buddhist as far up the arête as you can.

 For bonus points, you can start on the jug to the right (start hold of the Buddhist) and low traverse under the lip to the left to the start hold of Quiet Buddhist and then proceed from there.
content.protection: Pads, multiple are helpful because of a large boulder under the landing.
content.location: Just left of the pond cave crack, traverses the lip left.

content.description:
V4 might be the best grade to climb at Lincoln Woods and this one is a contender for the top. Start sitting at jug where the two walls meet and then follow the crack up and right. Top out when the jugs end when the crack turns the arete.

 The crux comes in the first few moves and with the option of using feet on the opposing wall to make the climb easier (probably v3+/v4-). This option may seem contrived but the cruxes climb differently with one being more subtle and core dependent while the other forces longer moves between the better holds.
content.protection: Multiple pads and spotter are best but the hardest moves are right near the beginning with an easy but not necessarily obvious top out.
content.location: Deepest point of the cave at an obvious jug, the heavily chalked right trending crack.

content.description: Start on Pond Cave traverse but halfway through the traverse climb up and finish up on the Leap Frog dyno.  Might be better in total than the direct start of Leap Frog.  Not any harder really but very fun moves.

Sit start at obvious arete to the right of the start of Leap Frog. You can use the big shelf for your feet or, to make it harder, don't use the shelf. Make your way up on decent pinch holds to a dyno that gains the right end of the crack of the pond cave traverse. Finish above as for Pond Cave Traverse on jugs.
content.location: Basically the direct start to the top out of Pond Cave Traverse.  It is the arete right of the deep cave just right of the start to Leap Frog.

content.description: Start seated all the way in the back corner of the hueco cave on a low jug. Traverse a crack along the left wall of the cave until you meet the start of lip service, and then finish through lip service.
content.location: Left side of pond cave

content.description: Start on the large hueco that tops out Gravity Hits, traverse right along the lip of the pond cave until you almost hit the top out to Quiet Buddhist. Nice jugs and heel hooks the whole way. Top out as you reach the left side of the prow that is Quiet Buddhist
content.protection: 1 pad and a spotter to move it.
content.location: starts at a hueco on the lip to the far right of the pond cave. Tops out at the high point of the cave before Quiet Buddhist.

content.description: Start all the way left on the quartz underclings eliminating the lower block and work up the left pinches with some techy foot work. Finish Leap Frog. This makes the entrance moves much harder. fun!
content.location: same start as leap frog. start on lowest undercling in roof to make for even more good times .

content.description: Another eliminate for Leap Frog, start on the same big underclings as for Leap Frog (or start on the sloping undercling a bit over to the left) and move up the crack on the right, move up to the jugs on the Pond Cave Traverse, and finish on the Pond Cave Traverse, the block is off. Basically an eliminate of the lower block on Centipede, an easier version of Under the Grid.
content.location: Starts on the same underclings as Leap Frog.

climbs.name: Leap Frog
climbs.fa: Bill Patton  (TR as Hard Christian) Ward Smith - bouldered

content.description: A very fun dyno using some uncharacteristic rock for lincoln woods.  Start low on underclings in the quartzite on the right side of the cave.  Move up mostly using crimps in the vertical crack and join the Pond Cave Traverse crack at its midway point.  Grab a jug up and left and then launch yourself up and right to a decent hold over the lip that is both far away and hard to see (scope out ahead).  Top out from there.  This is a fun problem to try even if V7 is outside of your range.
content.protection: pads, the dyno sends you flying.
content.location: Right side of the pond cave in the quartzite band.  Pretty much below the middle of the pond cave traverse.

content.description: same start for under the grid but instead of moving right to the arete follow the crack for leapfrog and finish on leap frog direct.

Start sitting on the low jug in the back corner of the hueco cave. Traverse left through holds in the crack running along the left side of the cave. Say goodbye to the spiders and top out directly above where the left wall meets the face.This problem is surprisingly fun for a dabby one, and there's a lot of potential for linkups / extensions.
content.location: Back left corner of pond cave

content.description: Start the same as Who Needs Hueco but instead of doing the big dyno move right (looking in the cave) on small holds topping out right of Who Needs Hueco.  Contrived.
start on lower left jug rail (feet for gravity hits)   up the quartz line into who needs hueco to finish. end on lip service nice addition makes for a better finish
content.location: all the way left in cave on big ledge for gravity hits

content.description: Climb the roof left (looking into the cave) of Who Needs Hueco.  Hard!
A fun little problem working your way up come nice angles ledges to a jug peak.
content.location: Located above Pond Cave about 10ft left of Rock is Lava. Start slightly scrunched on the lowest ledge working up on the left angled ledges eventually traversing left to the triangle jug. Topout from there. If you are too scrunched at the start and opt out of a pad be careful not to fall down the hole to the main cave.

content.description: start same as quiet Buddhist on big jug rail traverse into who needs hueco then finish up lip service.
content.location: starts very right side of cave roof moves all the way left then all the way right top out above start

content.description: Same beginning sequence as for Leap Frog but instead of doing the dyno just traverse right and top out as for Pond Cave Arete.
content.location: Below the middle of the pond cave traverse.

content.description: An awesome start variation to "The Quiet Buddhist", utilizing the full lip as a traverse. Most get this variation of the ascent before ticking the big throw start of TQB. Sit start at the base of the cave on an overly chalked jug shelf, that is the starting hold for the "Pond Cave Traverse". Pull up to good but technical crimps above the arete, traversing left until dropping down into the arete, joining the rest of TQB. Great climbing!
content.location: Deepest point in the cave, on obvious chalked block

content.description:
The Pond Cave is a longer cliff band that nearly climbs over the water and holds some of the steepest climbing in the woods with quality problems ranging from v3-v10.  The pond cave traverse and who needs hueco are must do problems for anyone who climbs regularly at Lincoln Woods. 

  Winter sun and summer shade but it can be a mosquito nightmare.
